I have the privilege of sharing earth- shattering news to the Marlette community.

The Gordon and Gayle Miller Foundation has decided to contribute $10,000 to the Marlette Band program, which will fully fund our "every 5th grader in band" campaign. This means, every single student in Marlette elementary will have an opportunity to be in band. 67 students will benefit this year, as well as thousands to come in the future. There are not many campaigns with as great of an impact on the future of students as this one. Truly, I'm blessed to lead this band program.

This community is demanding excellence in music. They continue to awe and amaze me by their willing to stand up and be counted as arts supporters. This endeavor would not be possible without exceptional leadership - Mrs. Sarah Mason Barratt and Mr. Jason Vislosky have been champions of this program rebuild, along with the entire Marlette Board of Education, led by President Jaime Macumber.

From the bottom of my heart, and on behalf of the students of Marlette, I thank all of you.

SNAP Outreach at Food Bank Council of Michigan
May 7 at 10:56 PM ¬∑

Pandemic EBT Update:

We have received many questions asking when and where families will be receiving P-EBT benefits for eligible students that received free or reduced price school meals.

It is not possible for us to tell you an exact date when you will receive these benefits. P-EBT benefits are being issued and cards are being mailed on an ongoing basis through mid-May.

Who is receiving these benefits? Students that are eligible for free or reduced price school meals will receive P-EBT benefits. This includes eligible students ages 5-18, as well as students under the age of 5 in early childhood education programs (such as Headstart and GSRP) and students ages 19- 26 enrolled in special education programs. This also includes students that attend schools where all students receive free school meals.

No application is required to receive P-EBT benefits.

Below is the letter that the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services has been mailing to families that do not currently receive Food Assistance Program benefits on the Bridge Card.

Today‚Äôs Challenge!

ELA
Gather as a family and have one person choose 3 objects in the room. In round robin fashion, that person begins a story. The person to the left adds to it, and then continues around the circle. The three objects have to be in the story somewhere. Everyone has to add to the story for every round. Determine how many round robins before the story starts. Shoot a video or write a summary of your story and post it for all to enjoy.

Family Music Playlist
We can use music as an expression to describe who we are as people. Your challenge is to create a playlist of at least two songs to describe your family. Your playlist can be linked to a website like Spotify or YouTube, or you can just list your songs below. Start by listening to your favorite songs, and don't be afraid to explore songs you haven't heard before! Have fun and enjoy yourself as you listen!
